College of Chemistry and Materials Science, Nanjing Normal University Nanjing 210023 China A series of bimetallic Zn-Co catalysts before and after calcination were prepared by simple MOFs template methods. The effects of calcination on their structures were investigated by XRD, FT-IR, TPD, XPS and EPR characterization methods, and their catalytic performances were compared in the cycloaddition reactions of CO2 and propylene oxide and acylation reactions of anisole and acetyl chloride, respectively. The results show that uncalcined ZnCo2-MOFs catalyst has excellent catalytic performance for cycloaddition reaction due to the presence of acid-base synergism, whereas the strong acidity of calcined ZnCo2OX catalyst is very favorable for acylation reaction. This is due to the fact that calcination changes the structure of ZnCo2-MOFs catalyst, causes charge migration on the surface and results in the conversion of lattice oxygen to oxygen vacancies, which brings a large difference in the acidity and basicity of catalysts. Graphical Abstract Proposed mechanisms in ZnCo catalyst-catalyzed cycloaddition and acylation. ga1 Keywords Calcination Change of acid-base sites Oxygen vacancies Dual catalytic systems Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In recent years, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted much attention because of their ultra-high porosity, high specific surface area and good pore structure, and they have been proven to be promising catalysts for various reactions [1–3]. On the other hand, MOFs are considered as ideal templates to obtain bimetallic oxides with excellent properties. During high-temperature thermal decomposition, MOFs materials can be converted into metals or metal oxides nanoparticles, while organic ligands are converted into carbon groups wrapped around the outer layer of these nanoparticles, which can prevent further agglomeration of nanoparticles. These metal oxides nanoparticles prepared by this method always have the advantages of controlled synthesis methods, adjustable surface state, good dispersion, and good catalytic activity [4,5]. In addition, some transition metal oxides can provide empty orbitals as electrophilic reagents or lone pairs of electrons as nucleophilic reagents in some chemical reactions, which can reduce the activation energy of reaction and then promote the reaction. As a waste product of many combustion processes, CO2 represents a potential carbon feedstock for the preparation of a variety of useful chemicals [6–9]. The literatures on the use and storage of CO2 identifies several economic routes in the chemical industry, and one important pathway is the use of CO2 in the synthesis of polymers, fuels and chemicals. Among these routes, the commercial synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 has been developed since 1950. The five-membered cyclic carbonate (propylene carbonate, PC for short) is widely used in the manufacture of pharmaceuticals and other fine chemicals such as lubricants, surface coatings, electrolytes for lithium batteries, solvents, fuel additives, polymer monomers and intermediates. Currently known reaction systems for the production of PC from CO2 and propylene oxide (PO) typically based on acid-base synergism, catalysts always consist of Lewis base sites acting as nucleophilic reagent and metal-centered Lewis acid species performing electrophilic attacks. Various types of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts have been proposed for the production of PC by coupling CO2 with PO, but uneven distribution or neutralisation of acidic and basic centers always exist in these catalysts [10]. Several literatures have reported the use of MOFs catalysts in cyclization reactions between epoxides and carbon dioxide. Tapiador and coworkers developed a Cu-based MOFs with a mixed architecture, called Cu-URJC-8 that can enhance the reactivity of CO2 and hydrophobic groups (pyridyl) to favor the formation of cyclic carbonates [11]. Wang and co-workers investigated a carbon-based catalyst with atomically dispersed dual Fe-Al sites (ADD-Fe-Al), this catalyst was formatted via a facile pyrolysis of bimetal-based (MOFs) Al/Fe-MIL-101-NH2, and exhibited superior catalytic conversion (>95%) and selectivity (>90%) at 70 °C with 0.5 MPa CO2, which indicates the effectiveness of dual-sites strategy on improving catalytic performance [12]. Meanwhile, Friedel-Crafts acylation reactions are mainly carried out by aromatic substrates with acyl moieties in the presence of acid catalysts [13]. The aromatic ketones products can be used as intermediates in pharmaceuticals, perfumes, dyes and agrochemicals [14]. Traditionally, this reaction has always been catalyzed by Lewis acids (e.g. ZnCl3, AlCl3, FeCl3, etc.) or strong protonic acids (HF and H2SO4). However, these reactions always require stoichiometric unit number of metal halides and generates large amounts of wastes. The same problem exists with the use of strong acids to catalyze these reactions [15]. From an environmental and economic point of view, there is an urgent need to address the above problems in cycloaddition and acylation reactions. Some solid acid catalysts have been widely used in acylation reactions. Zhang and co-workers reported their discovery on iridium-catalyzed carbonylation of phenol to aryl acetate with methyl iodide as the starting material under CO pressure at high temperature condition [16]. An and co-workers developed a new procedure on inexpensive metal cobalt-catalyzed highly efficient carbonylation of phenols to aryl acetates using organic peroxides as the methyl source [17]. In this paper, ZnCo-MOFs and Zn-Co composite oxides catalysts were obtained from simple template method before and after calcination respectively, and they were found to have excellent performance in cycloaddition and acylation reactions. Interestingly, the uncalcined ZnCo-MOFs showed excellent catalytic performance for the cycloaddition reactions of CO2 and PO, and corresponding Zn-Co composite oxides were very effective in catalyzing the acylation reactions of anisole and acetyl chloride. The reason for this is that the catalyst has good acidity and basicity prior to calcination, the acidity comes from the availability of metal ions (Zn2+) and the basicity derived from the N of imidazole as well as the lattice oxygen formed within the catalyst. The acid-base synergism within ZnCo-MOFs makes them favorable for cycloaddition reaction. In contrast, the transformation of Co3+ to Co2+ after calcination is accompanied by the formation of a large number of oxygen defects, and these oxygen defects constitute an additional source of acidity, so the higher acidity of catalysts after calcination gives excellent performance for acylation reactions. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report on the effects of MOFs catalysts before and after calcination on two different reactions. Importantly, they are green catalytic systems, whether it is cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides or Friedel-Crafts acylation reactions. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Preparation of ZnCon-MOFs catalysts According to previous literature [18], we prepared a series of ZnCon-MOFs nanomaterials based on the synthesis of Zn-ZIF-L crystals, which n represents different molar ratios of Zn/Co, as shown in the following procedure: the total amount required is 0.02 mol of Co(NO3)3-6 H2O and Zn(NO3)3-6 H2O were dissolved in 40 ml ethanol at room temperature. Then, 0.02 mol of imidazole was added and left to stand for 4 h. After the reaction, the mixture was centrifuged and washed three times with deionized water and finally washed once with ethanol. Finally, the samples were dried at 60 °C for 20 h in a vacuum oven and noted as ZnCo-MOFs, ZnCo2-MOFs, and Zn2Co-MOFs, and monometallic Zn-MOFs and Co-MOFs catalysts were prepared by the same procedure. 2.1.2 Preparation of ZnConOx bimetallic composite oxide catalysts ZnConOx bimetallic composite oxide catalysts were prepared by simple heat treatment of Zn-Co-MOFs catalysts. The above obtained ZnCo-MOFs catalysts were placed in a muffle furnace at 400 °C for 30 min (with a heating-up procedure of 0.5 °C/min) to obtain bimetallic composite metal oxides, denoted as ZnCoOx, ZnCo2Ox and ZnCo0.5Ox, respectively, and the corresponding monometallic oxides, ZnO and Co3O4, were obtained by calcination of Zn-MOFs and Co-MOFs. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Infrared spectral information of the catalysts was collected using Bruker Tensor 27 Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) with a KBr disk. The crystal structure of the catalysts was tested by X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Rigaku / Max-3 A) under Cu-Kα radiation (α = 0.15418 nm) and operated in the 2θ range of 5–80° with a scan rate of 0.5°/min. The surface electronic structure and chemical composition of the samples were determined by Thermo Fisher ESCALAB250XI X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), which has a K-Alpha surface analysis system with X-ray monochromatization. The spectra were recorded after vacuum purging of the samples and the calibration reference for the binding energy was C1s at 284.8 eV. The specific surface area and pore size distribution of the catalyst were measured by a physisorption instrument model ASAP 2010 at 77 K by obtaining the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of the catalyst. The morphology of the catalysts was measured by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (JSM-7600 F) and examined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) on an FEI Talos F200X instrument, and the acidity of the catalysts was examined by ammonia-temperature programmed adsorption-desorption (NH3- TPD) on an Auto Chem II 2920 with a thermal conductivity detector. Typically, a 100 mg sample is purged with helium at 120 °C for 60 min, then cooled to 50 °C, and 10% NH3(CO2)/ He gas is introduced in the reactor for 30 min of chemisorption, followed by heating the sample from 50° to 700°C for desorption with ammonia or CO2 at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. A Bruker EMX spectrometer operating at ∼9.40 GHz was used to take EPR data while an Oxford helium-gas flow system controlled the sample temperature [19]. 2.3 Catalytic performance evaluation Zn-Co-MOFs were used to catalyze the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides to obtain cyclic carbonates. A typical experimental procedure is as follows: In a 100 ml stainless steel batch reactor, 0.07 g MOFs catalyst and 0.57 ml PO and 5 ml N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) are added, and the reactor is purged with CO2 to displace air for 3 times, after which it is maintained at a constant CO2 pressure of 2 MPa. The reactor was placed in an oil bath at 180 °C for 10 h with stirring. After reaction, the mixture was cooled to room temperature, products were separated by and analyzed by a gas chromatograph (GC 9560) equipped with a capillary column (SE-54) and a flame ionization detector (FID). A typical reaction process of anisole with acetyl chloride was carried out in a 25 ml single-necked round-bottom flask equipped with a condenser and nitrogen atmosphere. Firstly, 0.15 g of catalyst, 5.9 ml of anisole and 1.3 ml of acetyl chloride were added sequentially to the round-bottom flask with a magnet. Then the flask was placed in a 100 °C oil bath and stirred for 6 h. Finally, products were separated by centrifugation and analyzed by a gas chromatography (GC 9560) with an SE-54 capillary column. For the reproducibility test of the reaction, the catalyst can be used directly after centrifugation. 2.4 Calculation methodology Catalysts were evaluated using a Density Functional Theory (DFT) theoretical level with the Material Studio package [20–22]. The calculations were carried out using a Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange-correlation function in the form of a generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [23]. Zn elements in ZIF-8 crystals synthesized by homogeneous MOFs template method were simply reconstituted at a Zn: Co ratio of 1:2. ZnO catalyst was subjected to the same reconstitution process. It is to be noted that due to the uncertainty in structure of MOFs, metal-nitrogen bound structural monomers were used to calculate adsorption energies in place of structurally larger MOFs. The adsorption energies of adsorbates on metal sites anchored inside the pore channel of catalysts were calculated as follows: E a =E adsorbate+catalysts -(E catalysts +E adsorbate ) Negative Ea values indicate that the adsorbed state is energetically favorable. In order to learn the charge transfer during adsorption, the calculation of charge density difference was also conducted. All The geometries were optimized by the BFGS algorithm [24]. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Catalyst activity comparison All the catalysts were used to catalyze the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with PO and the Friedel-Crafts acylation reaction of anisole and acetyl chloride, as shown in Tables 1–2. As can be seen from Table 1, main product of cycloaddition reaction is PC, and by-products are mainly propylene glycol, due to the unique three-dimensional structure of MOFs, monometallic Zn-MOFs and Co-MOFs showed good catalytic effects, especially when Zn-MOFs were used as catalysts, conversion of propylene oxide was as high as 71.9%, but their selectivity was poor, only about 56.1%, and Co-MOFs also had a PO conversion of 55.8%. In the blank experiment, the conversion was only 2.2% and the reaction almost did not occur due to the stability of CO2. In the bimetallic Zn-Co-MOFs, PC selectivity reached 99.9%, with the increase of Co/Zn molar ratio, PO conversion increased firstly and then decreased, and the best result was obtained at the Zn/Co molar ratio of 1:2, and PO conversion and PC selectivity were 94.2% and 99.9%, respectively. The catalyst showed the best catalytic performance of cycloaddition reaction, While, ZnCo2OX obtained by the calcination of ZnCo2-MOFs gave the worst catalytic effect with only 45.2% and 63.7% PO conversion and PC selectivity, respectively. Table 2 shows the catalytic activity of all the catalysts for the Friedel-Crafts acylation reaction of anisole and acetyl chloride, and the main product obtained from the reaction was p-methoxyacetophenone (P-MAP), and the by-products were mainly generated from the neighboring sites. As can be seen from the table, the conversion of anisole was 7.9% and the selectivity of P-MAP was 71.3% in the blank experiment. When monometallic ZnO and Co3O4 were used as catalysts, catalytic activity of ZnO was significantly higher than that of Co3O4, conversion of anisole was 47.5% and 29.2%, and the selectivity of P-MAP was only 93.0% and 91.5%, respectively. The bimetallic composite oxides with different Zn/Co molar ratios also exhibited different catalytic properties. The conversions of anisole were 80.3%, 85.6% and 79.7% when the Zn/Co molar ratios were 1:1, 1:2 and 2:1, respectively. It is noteworthy that catalytic activity is the highest when Zn/Co molar ratio is 1:2, conversion of anisole can reach 85.6% and the selectivity of P-MAP can reach 95.3%. However, uncalcined ZnCo2-MOFs catalyst showed the least capable of catalyzing the activation of acetyl chloride with only 51.2% and 62.9% conversion and P-MAP selectivity. The large difference between two catalysts based on the same process, prepared before and after calcination to catalyze different systems, aroused our curiosity. In order to investigate the differences in performance due to structural changes of catalysts, a series of characterizations were carried out to identify the key changes of these catalysts before and after calcination. Reaction conditions: catalyst 0.07 g, DMF 5. ml, 1,2-epoxypropane 0.57 ml, CO2 1.5 Mpa heated and stirred at 180 °C for ten hours. Reaction conditions: catalyst 0.15 g, anisole 5.9 ml, acetyl chloride 1.3 ml, heated and stirred for six hours at 100 °C under nitrogen protection. The effect of process conditions on the two reactions was investigated separately following a comparison of catalyst activity. MOFs catalysts for cycloaddition reaction and composite oxide catalysts for acylation reaction are shown in Figs. 1, 2 respectively. In Fig. 1, the effects of changing conditions on cycloaddition reaction is investigated in four dimensions: reaction temperature (a), reaction pressure (b), catalyst mass (c) and reaction time (d). When reaction temperature increased from 140 °C to 220 °C, PO conversion also showed an increasing trend, and the maximum PC yield was obtained at 180 °C. This may be due to the fact that high temperature promotes intermolecular collisions and bring CO2 molecules into full contact with epoxide, thus increasing the PC yield. When the pressure was increased from 0.5 MPa to 1.5 MPa, PO conversion increased substantially, from 40.2% to 88.1% with PC selectivity remaining above 91.8%. However, continued increase in pressure did not obtain favorable result. So 1.5 MPa was selected as the optimum pressure. Furthermore, to optimize catalyst loading, PC yield increased with increasing amounts of ZnCo2-MOFs catalyst. When the amount of ZnCo2-MOFs was increased to 70 mg, PC yield reached over 94.2%. While PC yield was only 92.4% using 90 mg of catalyst, probably due to a small amount of catalyst clusters blocking the contact of PO with CO2. From an economic point of view, the following reactions were carried out using 70 mg catalyst. Next, the PO conversion and PC selectivity steadily increased with time from 4 to 10 h. After 10 h of the reaction, PO was converted almost quantitatively with perfect PC selectivity, and then continuation of reaction resulted in formation of some by-products. In summary, using 70 mg ZnCo2-MOFs as a catalyst for the cycloaddition reaction, PO conversion was 94.2% and the PC selectivity reached 100.0% at 180 °C, 1.5 MPa CO2 and 10 h without any co-catalyst. In Fig. 2, acylation reaction conditions of anisole and acetyl chloride were optimized by reaction temperature (a), solvent ratio (b), catalyst mass (c) and reaction time (d). It can be seen that when reaction temperature increased from 60 °C to 100 °C, conversion of anisole increased from 57.1% to 90.3% and selectivity of P-MAP was up to 96.7%. When reaction temperature was increased to 120 °C, conversion of anisole and selectivity of P-MAP did not increase and remained almost unchanged. Therefore, we chose 100 °C as the optimum temperature in terms of yield. The amount of acylation reagents was also crucial to this reaction, and it was evident that when the acylation reagent/anisole ratio was 2.5:1, conversion of anisole could reach 90.3% and selectivity of para product could reach 96.4%. The amount of catalyst also influenced how fast this reaction occurred, when catalyst mass increased from 0.07 g to 0.30 g, conversion of anisole increased firstly and then decreased slightly, with 82.7%, 90.3%, 87.8% and 88.1% at different masses, respectively. At the same time, selectivity of P-MAP remained almost constant. Thus, the highest catalytic activity and product selectivity were achieved at 0.15 g. Finally, effect of reaction time was investigated: conversion of anisole reached its maximum (90.3%) at 6 h and selectivity of P-MAP was 96.4%. Interestingly, the conversion of anisole and selectivity of P-MAP remained almost constant with further increasing reaction time. Increasing reaction time would result in changes of catalyst surface properties, such as coking, which would affect catalyst activity. In summary, bimetallic ZnCo2Ox catalyst gave 90.3% conversion of acetyl chloride and 96.4% of P-MAP selectivity under the optimum conditions. From Fig. 3, it can be found that both MOFs and metal oxides show good stability for five cycles at the optimal reaction conditions. The catalysts before and after calcination reflect similarities in conversion as well as changes in selectivity. Conversion of reactants and the selectivity of target products remain basically stable. Even in fifth catalyst cycle study, conversion and selectivity of cycloaddition and acylation reached 93.2% / 99.3% and 89.7% / 96.1%, respectively. Therefore, we can know that all the catalysts perform well after five replicates, maintaining good stability in both reaction systems. Moreover, all catalysts were filtered off after 60 min from the hot reaction mixture, ICP analysis of filtrate confirmed that no leaching of Zn/Co species occurred, and further treatment of the filtrate under similar reaction conditions did not afford to any products. 3.2 Catalyst characterization XRD was mainly used to determine the phase and crystal structure. From Fig. 4a, we can learn that the X-ray diffraction peaks of all bimetallic catalysts match very well with the patterns of monometallic catalysts, which indicates that the entry of Zn2+ species into Co-MOFs（We can see that the characteristic peaks of Zn-MOFs weaken as the Co content increases.）does not cause structural damage and changes. Catalytic performance improves with homogeneous dispersion of Zn species in Co-MOFs. This is because the ionic radii of tetrahedrally coordinated Zn2+ (0.74 A°) and Co2+ (0.72 A°) do not differ much, so there are good interactions between them and they can also substitute for each other [25]. In Fig. 4b, the burr spurious peak turns into a clear and sharp diffraction peak, which indicates the formation of a highly crystalline material, this indicates that obtained samples have the same lattice framework, and these similar structures can be further confirmed by FT-IR spectroscopy. Furthermore, the diffraction peaks can be attributed to ZnO phase (JCPDS:36–1451), while Co3O4 phase (JCPDS:43. 1003) can be obtained, both of which are transformed from monometallic Co-MOFs and Zn-MOFs nanomaterials. Interestingly, bimetallic composite oxides catalysts ZnCoOx, ZnCo2Ox and ZnCo0.5Ox contain not only Co3O4 and ZnO phases but also a new ZnCo2O4 phase (JCPDS: 23–1390), it can be seen that as the Co2+ (or Zn2+) content decreases, the diffraction peaks of Co3O4 (or ZnO) phase decreases in intensity. This not only proves that the interaction between divalent Zn and divalent cobalt does exist, but also indicates that some of ZnO and Co3O4 are separated from the bimetallic oxides after calcination. Among the bimetallic composite oxides with different molar ratios, the highest diffraction peak intensity was observed from ZnCo2Ox catalyst, indicating that the strongest interaction between Zn2+ and Co2+ species was observed in this catalyst. As can be seen in Fig. 5a, the FT-IR spectra of all catalysts show very similar shapes with the main vibrational modes concentrated in the range of 400–2000 cm−1 [26]. The results show that all the samples have similar crystal frameworks, which is in agreement with XRD results. For typical vibrational modes, the peaks at about 424 cm−1 are attributed to Zn-N or Co-N stretching vibrations, the peaks near about 1142 and 1302 cm−1 belong to the C-H vibrational mode, while the peak at 1566 cm−1 corresponds to the CN vibration. Similarly, the coexistence of Co3O4 and ZnO is further confirmed by the spectra in Fig. 5b, where two strong absorption bands displayed by Co3O4 at 567 and 666 cm−1 are due to the Co-O stretching vibration [27]. An absorption peak was observed at 432 cm−1 corresponding to previously reported absorption peak defined as the stretching mode of ZnO [28]. However, in Fig. 5b, we can see a decrease in the absorption peak located at 424 cm−1 attributed to Zn-N or Co-N, demonstrating the enhanced binding of N in imidazole in ZnCoOx oxides after calcination, this phenomenon can be combined with XPS energy spectrum, TPD patterns, verifying weakened basicity of metal oxides catalysts after calcination. Moreover, the intensity of absorption peaks increases with the amount of Co. The morphology and particle size distribution of ZnCo-MOFs samples were examined by SEM analysis, as shown in Fig. 6, which clearly indicates that ZnCo-MOFs retain their well-defined rhombic crystalline morphology. Interestingly, in Fig. 6(b), ZnCo2-MOFs samples are uniformly dispersed small particles, which facilitates these catalysts to expose a large number of active sites. It can be seen from the figure that particle size of samples decreases and then increases as the Zn content increases, which may be due to the increase and decrease of the specific surface area of samples. It can be seen that the ZnCo2-MOFs (Fig. 6b) exhibit a relatively regular nanomorphology with an average particle size of 100 nm, which is made up of regular crystals without obvious agglomeration, compared with Zn-MOFs (Fig. 6a) and Co-MOFs (Fig. 6c), indicating that MOFs template method can effectively suppress the agglomeration of nanocatalysts. The field emission transmission electron micrographs depict the lattice characteristics of these catalysts, however, it is known that MOFs are not stable to the electron beam due to its structural limitations and normal lattice spacing is not obtained by high magnification transmission. Still, we can clearly find two different lattices in Fig. 6e, which proves successful integration of ZnCo ions, in agreement with XRD as well as IR results. The morphological characteristics of catalysts ZnO, Co3O4 and ZnCo2Ox are shown in Fig. 7(a-c). From the figures, it can be found that the surface of monometallic catalyst Co3O4 is distorted with many small holes and cracks (Fig. 7b), while monometallic catalyst ZnO shows an irregular structure with a dense accumulation of small pieces (Fig. 7a). On the contrary, the morphology of bimetallic composite oxide ZnCo2Ox was intermediate between the two monometallics (Fig. 7c). This confirms the co-growth of Co2+ and Zn2+ in a single catalyst during metal complexation [18]. The release of H2O, CO2 and other small molecules during the decomposition of MOFs catalysts also leads to the formation of some septa. Fig. 6(d-f) is almost identical to that of Fig. 7(d-f). Combining the TEM images of catalysts before and after calcination, we can obtain similar lattice characteristics of all these catalysts. The denser structure is formed at high temperature and corresponds with XRD findings. As shown in Fig. 8a, all MOFs exhibit H3 type IV isotherms, which are typical of mesoporous materials with pore sizes mainly distributed in the range of 4.6–9.2 nm, indicating that they have highly regular ordered mesoporous structures. ZnCo2-MOFs have the highest BET specific surface area 1571.8 m2/g, while ZnCo-MOFs and Zn2Co-MOFs were 1316.4 and 1248.5 m2/g, respectively. ZnCo-MOFs showed different hysteresis lines in N2 physisorption maps, which may be due to their mesoporous structure. The surface areas and pore volumes of several catalysts are presented in Table 3. The pore volumes of ZnCo2-MOFs, ZnCo-MOFs and Zn2Co-MOFs were found to be 0.8, 0.7 and 0.7 cm3/g. ZnCo2-MOFs had the highest average pore size and larger pore volume, indicating that reactants diffuse more easily into pore structure and contact active sites. The mesopore sizes of ZnCo2-MOFs, ZnCo-MOFs and Zn2Co-MOFs were 9.2, 8.4 and 7.8 nm, as calculated from corresponding Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore size distributions. The larger pore sizes can also indicate successful preparation of MOFs structures. In Fig. 8b, it is clear that the isotherms of samples can be classified as type IV, where ZnO and ZnCo2Ox catalysts show hysteresis echoes in the relative pressure range between 0.8 and 1.0 P0, while Co3O4 also shows insignificant hysteresis echoes at relative pressures greater than 0.9 P0. The surface area and pore volume of these five catalysts are listed in Table 3. It is obvious that the specific surface area of monometallic ZnO calculated by the BET method is 16.8 m2/g, while the specific surface area of monometallic Co3O4 is very small, 4.5 m2/g, and their pore volumes are 0.1 and 0. 01 cm3/g, respectively, while for bimetallic composite oxide ZnCo2Ox catalyst, the specific surface area is particularly large, 95.1 m2/g, and large pore volume at 0.3 cm3/g. Obviously, volume of 0.3 cm3/g is favorable to expose the active sites required for catalytic reaction. Since the pore structure of MOFs collapses during calcination, bore size of obtained material decreases, but the pores are enlarged. Meanwhile, enlarged pore structure cannot compensate for the loss of pore number due to collapse, resulting in the reduction of specific surface area and pore volume of calcined oxides. XRD and Fourier transform infrared characterization also corroborates the reason for the reduction of specific surface area. XPS analysis of these catalysts was performed to investigate the chemical state of bimetallic sample surface, and Fig. 9(a, b) shows symmetric deconvolution energy spectrum of Zn 2p before and after calcination of ZnCo-MOFs catalysts. In Fig. 9a, Zn 2p spectrum of sample shows two different peaks at 1021.5 and 1044.2 eV, attributed to Zn 2p3/2 and 2P1/2, respectively [29,30], and the shifts of two fitted peaks attributed to Zn2+ [31] binding energy peaks also reveal a strong fit between the Zn atom and 2-methylimidazole in ZnCo-MOFs. The strong fit between Zn atom and 2-methylimidazole in ZnCo-MOFs with Zn 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 peaks appearing at 1021.3 and 1044.4 eV can be attributed to Zn-O band, which is consistent with what others have reported [32,33]. Comparing a and b plots in Fig. 9, the Zn 2p energy spectrum of calcined catalysts does not change much, indicating that calcination essentially does not affect elemental zinc in catalysts. As shown in Fig. 9c, the Co 2p energy spectra for these four MOFs are demonstrated, the deconvolution peaks located at 779.6 and 781.9 eV are attributed to Co3+ and Co2+, respectively [34]. As shown in Table 4, the content of Co2+ was as high as 62.8% when Zn/Co molar ratio was 1:2, and Co2+ concentration on catalyst surface gradually increased with increasing Co content, which greatly improved exposure of acidic sites on the catalyst surface and promoted ring opening of epoxide. Fig. 9d shows Co 2p energy spectra of calcined oxides catalysts, with all samples except ZnO showing a similar shape with a satellite peak at 789.3 eV and a ΔECo 2p value (the energy band value between main peaks and satellite ones of Co 2p) of 15.07 eV, which indicates the presence of Co species in both Co2+ and Co3+ valence states on catalyst surface, which is in good agreement with the previous reports [35]. However, for the bimetallic composite oxides, the ΔECo 2p value is similar to that of the monometallic Co3O4, indicating that the valence state of Co element in bimetallic composite oxides is consistent with that of monometallic Co3O4, but the Co 2p 3/2 peak is biased toward lower energy, indicating an increase in the electron density of cobalt, which is due to the average electronic state of cobalt toward lower valence (measured as Co2+). According to the relative ratio of Co2+/Co3+ species, it can be seen from Table 5 that all bimetallic composite oxides catalysts have higher Co2+/Co3+ values than monometallic Co3O4, especially ZnCo2Ox has the highest ratio value (3.5), which indicates the presence of more Co2+ in ZnCo2Ox. It is noteworthy that the transformation of Co3+ species to Co2+ ones can produce more oxygen defects[36]. Therefore, as mentioned above, ZnCo2Ox has more active sites. For this phenomenon that Co3+ generates oxygen defects upon reduction to Co2+, O 1 s diagram of MOFs catalysts is shown in Fig. 10a, which can be divided into three types of oxygen: lattice oxygen (OL), surface oxygen (OS), and adsorbed oxygen (Oa). The adsorbed oxygen has the highest binding energy, located in the range of 531.4–532.3 eV, due to the presence of surface adsorbed O2, H2O and CO2 [37]. On the side of lower binding energy, two types of oxygen are present, where the lattice oxygen is located in the range of 528.8–529.5 eV, due to oxygen atoms bound to metal, while surface oxygen is in the range of 530.3–530 eV. Where the O 1 s peak of ZnCo2-MOFs can be attributed to lattice oxygen at 530.2 eV (OL) and adsorbed oxygen (OS) at 531.6 eV [38]. Table 4 shows the value of lattice oxygen in the catalyst before calcination, and it can be seen that the OL/OS of ZnCo2-MOFs reaches a maximum value of 2.9, providing more basic sites for cycloaddtion reaction. Apparently, MOFs with 1:2 Zn/Co molar ratio possesses more oxygen vacancies, which also raises a large number of active centers for reaction. In addition, the relative ratio of OS/OL in ZnCo2Ox catalyst is 2.17, which is higher than that of other bimetallic composite oxides, as shown in Table 5. Obviously, there are more surface oxygen vacancies in ZnCo2Ox catalyst, thus providing more active sites for acylation reaction. Oxygen vacancies located in the band gap of Co3O4 can also increase electrical conductivity of Co3O4 and excite electrons Co2+ and Co3+ on defect state thereby generating more defect sites [36]. In addition, lattice defects and distortions caused by oxygen vacancies can provide more active centers for acylation reaction and thus contribute to adsorption of acetyl chloride molecules [39]. It is noteworthy that the peaks of OS and OL in bimetallic composite oxides are shifted toward lower binding energies compared to monometallic ZnO and Co3O4, which should be due to the interactions of these two phases. XPS characterization of N elements was also performed for the catalysts before and after calcination. In Fig. 10c, the peaks at 398.3 and 400.4 eV are attributed to pyridine nitrogen and pyrrole nitrogen, respectively, which are consistent with FT-IR spectrogram (Fig. 4). Obviously, the content of pyridine nitrogen in the catalysts after calcination is lower than that of their partners before calcination, it is generally believed that pyridine nitrogen is present as a metal ligand sites [40–42] and pyridine nitrogen can act as basic sites to promote cycloaddition reactions, corroborating the stronger basicity of MOFs catalysts. The basic presence of MOFs catalysts is further approved. Given the differences on characterization of these catalysts before and after calcination, especially the differences in XPS energy spectra are much obvious. In view of the large differences in energy spectra of Co 2 P as well as O 1 S, coupled with the fact that lattice oxygen is a familiar basic site and oxygen vacancy is a strong acid site, we hypothesize that there is a relatively obvious difference in the acidity of oxides catalysts after calcination. For this reason, we characterized the acidity and basicity of CO2-TPD, NH3-TPD for MOFs catalysts as well as metal oxides catalysts, respectively, as shown in Fig. 11. Among them, CO2-TPD can detect the basicity of catalysts and NH3-TPD can detect the acidity of catalysts. From Fig. 11, it can be seen that the acidity of catalysts after calcination is stronger than that of their partners before calcination. Similarly, the basicity of catalysts before calcination is higher than that of their partners after calcination, a phenomenon that coincides with XPS energy spectrum: some lattice oxygen species in MOFs catalysts are converted into oxygen vacancies ones after high temperature calcination, resulting in change of acid-base properties. In addition, MOFs catalysts also contain some metal-binding bonds with pyridine nitrogen exhibiting basicity. High-temperature calcination caused breakage of bonds and loss of basicity, which further decrease the basicity of catalysts after calcination. For the important ZnCo2-MOFs and ZnCo2OX catalysts, they showed the largest differences in TPD profiles, we compared it carefully with other catalysts. As shown in Fig. 11a, b, ZnCo2-MOFs has strong absorption peaks at weak and moderately strong acids and is the only catalyst with strong basic absorption peak, and the presence of strong acid and base of ZnCo2-MOFs can be attributed to the doping of appropriate transition metals that better support the 3D structure of MOFs [43]. Furthermore, in combination with XPS findings, ZnCo2-MOFs have the highest content of lattice oxygen as well as pyridine nitrogen, both of which are present as basic sites. The catalyst acidity is merely derived from the presence of metal ions. According to Fig. 11c, d, comparing the acidity and basicity of catalysts before and after calcination, it can be observed that the acidity of all bimetallic oxides catalysts increase after high temperature calcination, accompanied by a decrease in basicity. Similarly, the acidity of ZnCo2OX after calcination was the highest, and the amount of its strong acidic sites also was the highest, but the basicity was the lowest among bimetallic oxides catalysts. Based on this phenomenon, we speculate that it is due to the strongest interaction of metal ions of ZnCo2-MOFs catalysts before calcination, which reduces the stacking and disperses[18], resulting in transformation of the originally highest amount of basic sites into acidic sites at most. The source of acidic sites is mainly due to the formation of oxygen vacancies after high temperature calcination, as well as the Lewis acidity formed by metal sites, this conclusion is supported by Table 4. Based on the above catalyst characterization, we can basically explain why catalytic performance of above two systems are so different: MOFs catalysts has strong acidic and basic sites in its structure to facilitate cycloaddition reaction, while formed metal composite oxides after calcination of MOFs are strongly acidic. To further explain the origin of strong acidity of calcined catalysts, the optimal samples were analyzed here on oxygen vacancies from EPR spectra. Multi-pulse electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) is a sensitive spectroscopic tool to monitor these oxygen vacancies resulting from charge transfer [44–47]. Fig. 12a depicts EPR spectra of ZnCo2Ox and ZnCo2-MOFs. Both exhibit resonance jumps centered at about 3510 G with a corresponding g value of 2.003, a value that implies the formation of oxygen vacancies in these materials [48]. It is clear from the figure that both of catalysts before and after calcination contain oxygen vacancies, but signal intensity of metal oxides is significantly stronger than that of MOFs. The double integration plot provides a visual illustration of concentration of oxygen vacancies in two samples (Fig. 12b). The results clearly show that signal intensity of oxygen vacancies is much higher in ZnCo2Ox after calcination than that of ZnCo2-MOF before calcination. This is in agreement with the results of XPS as well as TPD studies. 3.3 Reaction mechanism Based on experimental results and above characterization conclusions, we hypothesized to explain the contrasting catalytic effects of catalysts before and after calcination and carried out DFT theoretical calculations of reaction mechanism using VASP software to further elucidate catalyst adsorption. A comparison of adsorption energies of these two catalysts for acetyl chloride (AC) and propylene oxide is shown in Fig. 13. It is clear that adsorption capacity of ZnCo2-MOF for acetyl chloride is weaker than that for propylene oxide. In contrast, calcined ZnCo2Ox oxide were clearly more inclined to adsorb acetyl chloride molecules. Combined with the analysis of XPS and EPR results, the presence of more oxygen defects due to electron migration within calcined catalyst has a stronger ability to adsorb acetyl chloride. Finally, we have speculated on the reaction mechanism of this cycloaddition reaction as well as this acylation reaction based on our experimental results and previous reports. Where catalytic activity of ZnCo-MOFs in cycloaddition reaction arises from the coexistence of Lewis acidic metal centres (Zn and Co) and linking units (N). First, metal atom Zn/Co, which acts as Lewis acidic center, starts an electrophilic attack on the oxygen atom of epoxide and then epoxide is activated, which leads to opening of the ring on the less hindered side of epoxide and the formation of a partial positive charge on β-C atom. At the same time, in ZnCo2-MOFs, the N-basic part of imidazole linkage group at an adjacent position launches a nucleophilic attack on carbon atom of adsorbed CO2, forming a reactive oxygen anion. Finally, the interaction of ring-opening epoxide with this oxygen anion produces alkyl carbonate anion, which eventually passes through ring-closing step to produce a five-membered cyclic carbonate, while regenerating Zn/Co bifunctional catalyst can be used in next catalytic cycle. In acylation reaction, Co2+ catalyzes the adsorption of acetyl chloride molecules collaborating with oxygen vacancies [49], and in situ generation of chloride intermediate gives catalyst a negative charge, followed by π-electrons in carbon-carbon double bond on the aromatic ring attacking acyl cation, forming a cationic intermediate, and then negative charge attracts cationic intermediate, causing carbon atom to adsorb onto acyl group, lose a proton and reorganize double bond to form acetophenone thereby obtaining product [50,51]. 4 Conclusion Experimental and theoretical evidences showed that ZnCo-MOFs are acid-base bifunctional catalysts, where the uniformly dispersed rhombic crystalline morphology of ZnCo2-MOFs, its high specific surface area and large pore size provide more active sites for cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxide. Zn2+/Co2+ bimetallic catalytic centers in MOFs as Lewis acidic sites promoted ring opening of epoxide, while the N atoms in imidazole as basic sites adsorbed CO2 molecules to react with epoxide, in addition, some lattice oxygen was generated during the synthesis process, which further provided a basic environment for this reaction. In contrast, calcined Zn-Co composite oxides have more oxygen vacancies, which can produce more acidic active sites and thus exhibit excellent catalytic performance. It was very interesting that these catalysts before and after calcination have different acidity and basicity, ZnCo-MOFs are both acidic and basic, whereas Zn-Co complex oxides are strongly acidic, so calcination changes the structure of catalysts, turning a large number of Co3+ species into Co2+ species, leading to transformation of some lattice oxygen into oxygen vacancies, which in turn leads to a change in the acidity and basicity of catalysts, thus affecting its effects on two different catalytic systems. Effect of calcination on structure is rarely mentioned in existing literatures, these studies always focus on some changes caused by structure themselves and are limited to a single catalytic system, this paper innovatively mentions structure-induced changes of acid-base properties on ZnCo-MOFs before and after calcination and applies them into two different catalytic systems. More studies on catalytic properties affected by calcination will continue to be investigated in our group. coredata.dc:description: A series of bimetallic Zn-Co catalysts before and after calcination were prepared by simple MOFs template methods. The effects of calcination on their structures were investigated by XRD, FT-IR, TPD, XPS and EPR characterization methods, and their catalytic performances were compared in the cycloaddition reactions of CO2 and propylene oxide and acylation reactions of anisole and acetyl chloride, respectively. The results show that uncalcined ZnCo2-MOFs catalyst has excellent catalytic performance for cycloaddition reaction due to the presence of acid-base synergism, whereas the strong acidity of calcined ZnCo2OX catalyst is very favorable for acylation reaction. This is due to the fact that calcination changes the structure of ZnCo2-MOFs catalyst, causes charge migration on the surface and results in the conversion of lattice oxygen to oxygen vacancies, which brings a large difference in the acidity and basicity of catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Zn-Co bimetallic catalysts before and after calcination: Research on their different properties for cycloaddition and Friedel-Crafts acylation reactions
